text: Today we're looking at a video recently

dead. In 2023, Ford postponed 12 billion
dollars of their planned EV production.
GM expected to produce between 200,000
to 250,000 EVs in 2024, down from the

Volkswagen cancelled the development of
a $2 billion EV factory in Germany. So,
what happened? How did a once promising

In a recent IEA global EV outlook

35% yearonear in the first three months

that electric car sales in 2025 are

to represent more than one quarter of
cars sold worldwide. Literally one in
four cars will be electric this year. So
no, EVs are not on the decline when you

electric version cost
21,400, making the electric option more

version only cost
23,800. So, yes, the average purchase
price of a new EV is slightly higher
than that of a gas powered vehicle, a
comparable one. Anyways, however, as
they completely dismissed in this video,
the real cost is across 5 years, not 3
years. And when you look at the real

a better deal. I'll put links to several

of course electricity cost, gas mileage,

the insights from Recurrent to sell my

offered when I got a quote from CarMax.
CarMax was the first person I went to
just because it's easy and generally a

to
bit.ly/me-recurrent or check the link in

when you take into account how narrow

But you also have to qualify for the tax

The consumers will also have to meet

There can be a lot of hidden costs.

California, unsurprisingly, is rated the
most. The difference between the two in
EV infrastructure is huge. California
has almost
51,500 chargers in total. Mississippi

now has
757 EV chargers, far more than they

and then making a generalization about
that for everyone else, thinking that
this is kind of standard for all the EV
owners in the country. And that's
absolutely not true. I mean, first off,
80% of charging today still happens at
home. And in Mississippi, they have a
large rural population with an
exceedingly high home ownership rate
compared to other states. What that
means is that most people in Mississippi
do not need and likely will never need

on a road trip. And if you did want to
include every single place in
Mississippi that you could charge, that
would literally be every home, town
home, garage out there and public space,
it would outnumber gas stations probably
five or six to one. So really, when you
think about where you can charge, it's
anywhere that there's electricity. So
they can cherrypick some numbers here,
but that's not the real situation. And I
think they and probably anyone looking
at this really does know that that's the

that twothirds of US housing units had a

opportunities for EV adoption. And
another study from the Pew Research
Center in May of 2024 showed that about
6 in 10 Americans live within 2 miles of

convenient way. In the meantime, where

very different amounts for electricity
depending on where in the country they

monopoly is. In 2020, for example,
Louisiana residents paid an average of
10 cents per kilowatt hour. Residents in
Hawaii paid 33 cents per kilowatt hour,
3.3 times more expensive than Louisiana.
Yes, electricity costs vary 100%. The
